Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide with or without K was prepared and characterized by XPS, TPR H2, TPD NO, TPD O2 and TPD NO+O2. NO decomposition was performed over catalyst activated in different atmosphere (N2, He, O2). Presence of oxygen during activation changed the course of surface stabilization but did not affect NO conversion achieved at steady state. O2 desorbed as a reaction product does not affect the reaction rate for NO inlet concentration of 400 - 8000 ppm, but presence of O2 in inlet gas mixture (0.05 - 3 mol.%) has significant inhibiting effect. Transition metals in octahedral coordination represent sites for NO chemisorption, while potassium ensures NO oxidation to surface nitrites, which are indispensable reactive species. Oxygen desorption was the slowest reaction step, while N2 desorption was fast. Oxygen inhibition was ascribed to oxidation of NO* species on the octahedral Co3+ and Mn3+ to more stable surface nitrates making NO* species as limiting reactant. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NO Mixed oxide Oxygen effect Mechanism TPD 1 Introduction NO is one of the major atmospheric pollutants and it is unavoidable in trace amounts when fossil fuels or biofuels are combusted, e.g., in energy conversion processes. Direct NO decomposition to N2 and O2 theoretically represents the simplest and the most attractive solution for NO abatement, since it does not require addition of any reducing agent. A number of different catalysts have been examined for this reaction [1, 2]. However, activities of the catalysts proposed up to now are not high enough for the use in practical application, especially due to the inhibition effect of other components typical for industrial waste gasses such as O2 or CO2 [1]. The catalysts so far developed are in many cases very little active below 650 °C and the research was mainly focused on the study of activity in inert gas and the effect of other components was significantly less studied. Changes in catalytic activity in the presence of oxygen were published on Cu-ZSM-5 [3-5], Pd/Al2O3 [6], K/Co3O4 [7, 8], perovskites [9, 10] mixed oxides [1] and oxides promoted by rare earth elements [11]. For all catalysts, a significant decrease in catalytic activity was observed with the increasing concentration of O2 in the reaction mixture [1, 12] - a negative reaction order with respect to oxygen was reported. Inhibiting effect of O2 was more significant at higher NO concentrations, due to the higher concentration of O2 produced from NO decomposition [13]. In spite of agreement that oxygen negatively influences catalyst performance for NO direct decomposition, the explanation of such effect is not straightforward and differs in literature [13]. Moreover, oxygen inhibiting effect was published by some authors to be temperature and contact time sensitive [14]. According to [13, 15], it appears to be more significant at lower reaction temperatures. The understanding of oxygen functioning is based on the understanding of reaction mechanism, which is often not exactly known. Several works have been devoted to the study of NO decomposition mechanism [6, 8, 16-18] including one over cobalt based mixed oxide catalyst [19] performed in inert conditions without oxygen presence. However, the detailed mechanisms in oxygen presence and feature of active sites on cobalt mixed oxides are still a matter of debate and different models and reaction steps have been proposed. If one focused on cobalt spinel modified by alkali metals which represents important class of deNOx catalyst [7, 8, 20], published results regarding decomposition mechanisms can be summarized as follows. NO direct catalytic decomposition typically starts by NO adsorption which may theoretically occur on both the octahedral and the tetrahedral cobalt surface sites as well as on the coordinatively unsaturated oxygen anions [21]. Following these modes, NO molecule can (i) interact with surface lattice oxygen anionic species to form ionic adsorption species with negative charge, (ii) adsorb on single metal cations via the nitrogen end of the molecule, resulting in the formation of mononitrosyl or dinitrosyl adducts or (iii) adsorb on dual cationic sites resulting in bridging bidentate or monodentate adducts [21]. In all studied cases, the binding through nitrogen atom was much more favorable then via oxygen moiety. After NO adsorption, surface reactions, which can be very fast, leading to formation of different kinds of surface species take place and these species can subsequently react with each other or even with another NO gaseous molecule. The surface ionic nitrogen oxospecies are commonly mentioned as reaction intermediates in NO decomposition. Nitrate and nitrite ions are sufficiently stable on the surface to function as intermediates at the elevated reaction temperatures although the particular form of the intermediate remains unclear [13]. Haneda [8, 17] proposed that over alkali metal doped Co3O4 catalysts, NO2 − species probably react with another NOx adspecies resulting in the formation of N2Ox intermediates, which decompose very fast into gaseous N2 and adsorbed oxygen species. In the presence of oxygen, NO2 − species can be oxidized by gaseous oxygen to NO3 − [8]. Formation of hyponitrite ion (N2O2)2−, especially on alkaline earth metal oxides and formation of N2O adspecies together with surface oxygen was also reported in [22]. Also in this case, it was reported that surface N2O further decomposes to form N2 and surface oxygen and in the following steps, gaseous or adsorbed NO react with surface oxygen to form NO2 − and NO3 −. Here the charge neutrality for formation of NO2 − or NO3 − species can be retained by oxidation of Mex+ cation to form Mex+1. NO3 − can be also formed by disproportionate adsorption of three NO molecules or by adsorption of NO on the strongly adsorbed surface oxygen [23, 24]. While nitrogen is evolved by reaction of other species than adsorbed nitrogen atoms, oxygen desorption proceeds via desorption of two vicinal adsorbed oxygen atoms; surface migration of adsorbed oxygen atoms can also occur [6, 14]. Different rate determining steps were assumed over metal oxides: the oxygen desorption [18], adsorption of NO on the active site [24], attack of second NO molecule on the oxygen vacancy [25], NO2 formation, N2O formation and decomposition or formation of intermediates. Anyway, the suggestion that the formation of N2 is directly caused from the collision of two activated nitrogen oxospecies and that formation of O2 is combined by the two left oxygen atoms is valid across a lot of different studies [26] with exception of Zhu at al., who proposed different mechanism of NO decomposition on perovskite [26-28]. In this mechanism, the oxygen desorption step is not preferred way of O2 formation and oxygen desorption is described as indirect desorption with adsorbed NO as intermediate. The given mechanism is running via circulatory dissociation of NO2: two gaseous NO molecules are at first adsorbed and dissociated into N2 and atomic oxygen, which then reacts with another NO to form the adsorbed NO2. After that the adsorbed NO2 desorbs and dissociates into NO and O2 in the gas phase. In this process, NO2 acts as an intermediate in O2 formation. Also a lot of different types of active sites were published for oxide catalysts for NO decomposition; e.g. single oxygen vacancy, vacancy pair site, lattice oxygen atoms, surface adjacent lattice oxygen atoms, vacancies occupied by chemisorbed oxygen atoms or cations of transition metals [1, 22] as well as different forms of oxygen species which can be present on metal oxide surfaces: O2(ad), O2−, O2 2−, O − [22]. Various surface reactive oxygen species formed upon interaction of O2 with cobalt spinel at various conditions were discussed in details by Zasada et al. [29-31]. It was shown that surface cobalt cations work in tandem constituting dual cobalt octahedral-octahedral and octahedral-tetrahedral sites for O2 activation. The metal-oxo species were formulated in terms of O − moieties coupled to cobalt ions differing in stabilities and mobility. The reason for such wide range of results can be the fact that NO molecule can adsorb either dissociatively or molecularly depending on the type of active metal and on the conditions of adsorption and that the chemisorption of the reactants can cause adsorbate-induced restructuring of the surface [6]. Chemisorption of NO on the surface often depends on surface temperature, surface coverage, crystal plane and the concentration of surface defects [21, 32]. Based on different mechanisms, different explanations of oxygen effect were published. It was suggested that oxygen decreases the number of defects [13] or inhibits the desorption of oxygen from the catalyst [13]. According to Haneda et al. [8], the decrease in activity is caused by oxygen competitive adsorption onto the active sites and thus inhibition of NO adsorption. Moreover in the presence of oxygen, NO2 − species can be oxidized by gaseous oxygen to NO3 −, which behaves as a spectator species and should account for negative influence of O2 on the decomposition reaction [8]. Xie et al. [13] found out based on kinetic results at 750 °C on Ba/MgO catalyst that even oxygen effect is negative, this is net effect and is composed from two different effects which are positive and negative. A positive effect is through formation of NO2 − ions, while the negative effect through formation of NO3 −. Also group of Tofan [14] presented results suggesting that oxygen, in spite of having an inhibiting effect, might also be involved as a reactant, i.e. takes part in the formation of the reaction intermediate. This suggests that some surface oxygen species play a role of an active site [33]. NO decomposition is redox type of reaction and oxygen moieties participate in almost all reaction steps and can modify catalyst surface. Based on literature results, it is obvious that oxygen can play dual role in the NO decomposition mechanisms. Moreover from our previous experience, the NO decomposition reaction needs long time for stabilization [34, 35], which can also be connected with oxygen functionalities during this period. We have already studied mechanism of NO decomposition in inert gas without presence of oxygen in the feed over Co-Mn-Al mixed oxide modified by different K amounts [19] by transient state studies, in situ DRIFTS and TPD NO. Since in [19] the catalyst contained high amount of cobalt and oxygen is commonly present in high concentration in almost all off gasses, in current work we decided to investigate the effect of oxygen on NO direct decomposition over Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide catalyst (Co:Mn:Mg:Al molar ratio of 3:1:1:1) promoted by optimal amount of potassium (2 wt.%) where the part of expensive and toxic cobalt was replaced with magnesium [36]. The results are compared with those obtained for potassium non-promoted catalyst. The main aim is evaluation of oxygen effect on NO catalytic decomposition when present (i) in activation atmosphere during catalyst pre-treatment before catalytic reaction, (ii) in reaction mixture coming from NO decomposition and (iii) in inlet mixture. The evaluation is based on the catalytic results and results of temperature programmed desorption technique. TPD makes it possible to detect adsorbed species with different thermal stability, i.e. with the different bond strength with the surface and allows deduction of considerations regarding reaction mechanism and active sites particularity. The investigation of the oxygen effect on NO catalytic decomposition could bring substantial contribution to the active catalyst development. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The Co-Mg-Mn-Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursor (Co:Mg:Mn:Al molar ratio of 3:1:1:1) was prepared by co-precipitation of corresponding nitrates (2 litres of solution with 291 g Co(NO3)2•6 H2O (Penta, 99% purity), 85 g Mg(NO3)2•6 H2O (Penta, 99% purity), 84 g Mn(NO3)2•4 H2O (Penta, 97% purity), and 125 g Al(NO3)3•9 H2O (Penta, 98% purity)) with Na2CO3/NaOH solution (2.4 litres of solution with 242 g Na2CO3 (Penta, 99% purity) and 127 g NaOH (Penta, 98% purity)) at 30 °C and pH 10. The precipitated solid was subsequently washed, dried at 60 °C and calcined at 670 °C for 4 h in air. The calcined product was sieved to obtain particle size 0.160–0.315 mm and marked as Co-Mg-Mn-Al. Part of Co-Mg-Mn-Al sample was impregnated by the pore filling method using KNO3 (Penta, 98% purity) water solution in order to have nominal K content in the catalyst 2 wt.%. Impregnated sample was dried at 60 °C, recalcined at 700 °C for 4 h in air, sieved to obtain particle size 0.160–0.315 mm and marked as K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al. The chemical composition of prepared catalysts was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) using a SpectrAA880 instrument (Varian) after dissolving the samples in hydrochloric acid. Details of other methods used for physico-chemical characterization of both catalysts were already published in our previous work [36]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was applied for superficial elemental analyses (X-ray photoelectron spectrometry ESCA 3400, Kratos Analytical Ltd., Manchester, UK) at a base pressure lower than 5 . 10−7 Pa, using the polychromatic Mg X-ray source (Mg K, 1253.4 eV). For the spectra, the Shirley background was subtracted, and the elemental compositions of layers were calculated from the areas divided by corresponding response factor. Calibration to adventitious carbon (284.8 eV) was applied. XPS was applied to non-activated sample and samples activated in different atmospheres (20 mol.% O2 in N2 and He). Activation was done by heating the sample to 650 °C with rate 5 °C/min, dwelling 1 h at 650 °C and cooling to ambient temperature in the same atmosphere. The sample was closed in the reactor in corresponding atmosphere after activation. Fast transfer to XPS chamber from the reactor was applied. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR H2) of the catalyst (0.08 g) activated in different atmosphere (20 mol.% O2 in N2 and He) was performed with a H2/Ar mixture (10 mol.% H2), flow rate 50 ml min−1 and linear temperature increase 20 °C min−1 on Autochem II (Micromeritics). A change in H2 concentration was detected with inbuilt TCD detector. 2.2 NO catalytic decomposition tests Catalytic decomposition of NO was performed in an integral fixed bed stainless steel reactor of 6 mm internal diameter at the temperature range of 560–700 °C, atmospheric pressure, inlet gas mixture 400–8000 ppm NO + 0–10 mol.% O2 balanced by nitrogen or helium, WHSV = 6 l g − 1h−1, catalyst amount of 0.5 g and total flow rate 49 ml/min at STP. The catalyst was activated in 50 ml min−1 of N2 or He or 20 mol.% O2 in N2 for 1 h at 650 °C. Then NO catalytic decomposition at 650 °C was performed at least for 24 h. After this period, when stable performance was observed, the temperature dependence of NO conversion was launched with cooling rate of 5 °C/min and catalysts activity was followed for 3 h at each temperature (640 °C, 620 °C, 600 °C, 580 °C and 560 °C). After that the catalyst was heated back to 650 °C in order to evaluate stability of the sample and the effect of NO amount was measured. Afterwards the sample was heated to 700 °C and after achieving steady state conversion level, the effect of oxygen amount was measured. The concentration of inlet mixture was obtained by switching the flow to the bypassed line for each set of adjusted inlet concentrations. Steady state NO outlet concentration was used for NO conversion evaluation. The infrared analyzer (Ultramat 6) equipped with NO2/NO convertor (TESO Ltd.) was used for online analysis of NO and NO2 and gas chromatograph (Agilent) with TCD and molecular sieve CP-Molsieve 5A column was used for analysis of O2 and N2 during catalytic experiments. Presence of N2O was checked on FTIR spectrometer (Antaris IGS, Nicolet). N2O formation during steady state NO decomposition reaction was not observed in this study. 2.3 Temperature programmed desorption and transient state experiments Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of NO was carried out on AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA). Quadrupole mass spectrometer RGA 200 (Stanford Research Systems, Prevac) was used for monitoring of m/z = 32 (O2), m/z = 28 (N2), m/z = 30 (NO), m/z = 14 (NO2), m/z = 44 (N2O, CO2) and m/z = 40 (Ar as tracer) signals. Since the signal m/z = 14 and 44 was zero all the time with exception emphasized in the text, neither NO2, N2O nor CO2 was present during these experiments. Three different procedures of TPD were applied: (1) Catalyst heating, (2) TPD NO and (3) TPD NO+O2. Catalyst heating was performed as follows: the sample (0.09 g) was purged in He (50 ml min−1) at 650 °C for 1 h, cooled to 50 °C in He flow and constant temperature of 50 °C was maintained for 30 min. The desorption was carried out in flow of He (50 ml min−1) in temperature range 50–650 °C with heating ramp of 20 °C min−1. For temperature programmed desorption of NO (TPD NO), at first the sample (0.09 g) was activated at 650 °C for 1 h. The activation consisted from heating and isothermal step in (i) He (50 ml min−1) or (ii) 20mol.% O2 in He (50 ml min−1) or (iii) 10mol.% H2 in Ar (50 ml min−1). NO saturation step was done by step change of NO and Ar tracer concentrations at reactor inlet from 0 to 0.998 mol.% NO and from 0 to 9800 ppm Ar in He and back to 0 ppm NO and Ar at 650 °C, and once again to 0.998 mol% NO and 9800 ppm Ar at atmospheric pressure and total flow rate of 50 ml min−1 was applied just after activation. Then the sample was cooled to 50 °C in the same atmosphere (NO + Ar in He), and constant temperature of 50 °C was maintained for 30 min. NO was switched off and the sample was purged from physically adsorbed compounds by He flow (50 ml min−1) at 50 °C for 30 min. TPD NO was carried out in flow of He (50 ml min−1) in temperature range 50–650 °C with heating ramp of 20 °C min−1. For temperature programmed desorption of NO+O2 (TPD NO+O2), at first the sample (0.09 g) was activated at 650 °C for 1 h. The activation consisted from heating and isothermal step in He (50 ml min−1). Step change of 0.5 mol.% NO + 5 mol.% O2 and Ar tracer concentrations at reactor inlet was applied at 650 °C and the feed was kept for 1.5 h. Then the sample was cooled to 50 °C in the same atmosphere and constant temperature of 50 °C was maintained for 30 min. NO was switched off and the sample was purged from physically adsorbed compounds. Two different atmospheres compositions were tested: (i) He or (ii) 2 mol.% O2 in He flow (50 ml min−1) at 50 °C for 30 min. TPD NO+O2 was carried out in flow of (i) He or (ii) 2 mol.% O2 in He He (50 ml min−1) in temperature range 50–650°C with heating ramp of 20 °C min−1. Temperature programmed desorption of O2 (TPD O2) was performed on AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA). Quadrupole mass spectrometer RGA 200 (Stanford Research Systems, Prevac) was used for monitoring of m/z = 32 (O2), m/z = 28 (N2), m/z = 14 (NO) and m/z = 44 (N2O, CO2) signals. Two different procedures were applied. First (TPD O2, 650 °C), the sample (0.09 g) was purged in He (50 ml min−1) at 650 °C for 1 h, then the helium flow was replaced by 50 ml min−1 of 10 mol.% O2 in He and this was maintained for 1 h at 650 °C. Than the sample was cooled to 50 °C in the same atmosphere (O2 + He), and constant temperature 50 °C was maintained for 30 min. Afterwards the sample was purged from physically adsorbed compounds by He flow (50 ml min−1) at 50 °C for 90 min and finally, the TPD was carried out in He flow (50 ml/min) in temperature range 50–650 °C with heating ramp of 20 °C min−1. The second type of TPD O2 measurement (TPD O2, 50 °C) was done similarly as previous one; only the oxygen saturation step was performed at 50 °C for 1 h instead of 650 °C. Oxygen concentration was determined using two points calibration of MS by the calibration standards (480 ppm O2/He and pure He). Transient state experiments of NO decomposition were evaluated from NO saturation step of TPD NO measurement (see description above). Signals obtained from mass spectrometer were recalculated to 0.1 g of sample, smoothed and deconvoluted in OriginPro2018. For some runs, the MS signals were recalculated by calibration procedure after applying of known concentrations of calibration gasses (480 ppm O2, 510 ppm N2, 778 ppm NO) after each measurement run. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of prepared catalysts The results of chemical analysis are consistent with the theoretical content of Co, Mg, Mn and Al resulting in molar ratio Co:Mg:Mn:Al of 3:0.9:1:1. Slightly lower content of K (1.5 wt.%) was observed than was used for impregnation procedure probably due to thermal desorption of potassium during calcination process [34]. Detailed physical-chemical characterization of both catalysts was already published elsewhere [36], where presence of mixed oxide with spinel structure and potassium manganese oxide attributed to K2Mn4O8 and/or K1.39Mn3O6 were found by XRD. The phases containing potassium and cobalt simultaneously were not identified, while potassium addition caused slight shift of spinel reflections to higher diffraction angles [36]. The surface compositions of K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst, non-activated and upon activation in oxidizing atmosphere (20 mol.% O2 in N2) and in inert (He) were determined by XPS. Particular areas of spectra used for determination of composition were Co 2p, Mn 2p, O 1 s, Al 2p, Mg 2 s, Na 1 s, K 2p and C 1 s. It was not possible to use spectra of Mg 2p because of overlapping with dominating Mn 3p. Surface composition is given in Table 1 . Since the carbon tape was used for sample fixing, the observed carbon presence is not taken into further consideration. Surface molar stoichiometry and a comparison with bulk composition are shown in Table 2 . The surface of catalyst is substantially enriched in aluminum (approx. 5 times) and to a lesser extent in manganese and magnesium (approx. 2 times). Similar surface enrichment in Mn and Al was observed for K-doped Co-Mn-Al mixed oxide in our previous works [37, 38]. Segregation of Al 3+ on the Co-Al mixed oxide surface was described also by other authors [39, 40]. Potassium surface concentration is also significantly higher than in bulk as expected because of the impregnation method used. In this case, all K promoter is located on the catalyst surface similarly as in works [37, 38]. Generally, surface enrichment is connected with the mobility of metals cations due to their lower surface energies - Al (1200 mJ m − 2) and K (79–119 mJ m − 2) compared to Co (1500 mJ m − 2) [41, 42], which order roughly corresponds to melting points of metals. Activation of K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst in inert and oxidation atmosphere caused only small changes in surface stoichiometry (Table 2). Enrichment of the surface by magnesium, manganese and aluminum is slightly lower for He activated catalysts in comparison to non-activated and O2 activated one. In case of aluminum, the change is more pronounced than in case of magnesium and manganese which change is at the edge of deviation of measurement (between 5 and 10 relative%). For all samples, potassium showed one chemical state (292.55 ± 0.05 eV for K 2p3/2) typical for K-Mn-O phase [35]. Deconvoluted XPS spectra of the individual elements Co 2p, Mn 2p and O 1 s (Fig. S1, S2 and S3, Table 3 ) showed similar features referring to the presence of the same components on all treated catalysts. The Co 2p region consisted of two main photoemission maxima Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 with the spin-orbital splitting of 15.3 ± 0.1 eV. The energy separation together with satellite structure confirmed presence of both Co2+ and Co3+ chemical states [43]. Deconvolution of Co 2p3/2 (maximum at 780.2 ± 0.1 eV) to three peaks (779.85, 781.35 and 783.45 ± 0.1 eV, where first peak corresponds to Co2+ and the second and third peaks correspond to Co3+) and two satellites showed ratio Co2+/Co3+ of 1.9 ± 0.3 [37]. The Mn 2p region consisted of Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 with spin-orbital splitting of 11.7 ± 0.1 eV. Position (641.9 ± 0.1 eV) and width of Mn 2p3/2 peak indicated presence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ states. Mn 2p3/2 region was fitted by two peaks at 641.5 and 643.4 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively, showing Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio around 2.4 ± 0.3 eV [37, 44]. From obtained results it implies that different activation did not result in a observable change in the proportion of Co2+/Co3+ and Mn3+/Mn4+ oxidation states. Oxygen spectra were composed of the two peaks at 529.5 ± 0.15 eV and 531.2 ± 0.15 eV corresponding to lattice oxygen and chemisorbed oxygen, respectively [45]. Total content of oxygen (Table 1) revealed that, surprisingly, activation in O2 did not provide sample with the highest oxygen content. More insight into this matter is provided in Table 3 showing the content of different oxygen states. In oxygen activated samples, the lattice oxygen content was slightly higher in comparison with fresh sample, which is in accordance with the expectation, but the difference was lower than standard deviation of deconvolution provided by Monte Carlo simulations build in CasaXPS software. The amount of lattice oxygen decreased for sample activated in He which confirmed formation of oxygen vacancies similarly as in the case of Co3O4 at temperature > 600 °C [29]. Much higher differences were observed for chemisorbed oxygen species. The amount of chemisorbed oxygen decreased due to high-temperature treatment in comparisons to fresh catalyst and the decrease was more evident if the treatment was performed in oxygen free conditions (in He). Positions of selected deconvoluted peaks are in the Table 4 . There is no difference in position of deconvoluted peaks between non-activated and O2 activated samples. For He activated sample, a small shift to lower binding energies can be observed. The shift of 0.1 eV is at the edge of standard deviation, but it was observed for all major elemental lines from the sample. In addition, the shift is more pronounced for deconvoluted Mn 2p peaks; hence, it is not a systematic shift of whole spectra. This shift in binding energies suggests that due to the He activation, a local chemical environment was changed pointing toward a slight oxygen deficiency and formation of vacancies. The change in K/Co-Mn-Al reducibility due to different activation pretreatment was verified by TPR H2. The TPR H2 results of the sample activated in Ar (as common step before TPR measurement) was already shown in [36]. In Fig. 1 there are results of TPR H2 performed after activation in 20 mol.% O2/N2 and in He. The same shape of the peaks was observed after activation in inert gasses (Ar [36] and He), while after activation in oxygen reach stream, changes are observable, especially in low temperature region (below 300 °C). The newly emerged low-temperature maxima can be ascribed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species and/or to the reduction of Co4+ formed by the oxidation of surface [46]. 3.2 Steady state catalytic decomposition of NO Fig. 2 shows the activity of Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide (non-modified) and Co-Mg-Mn-Al promoted by potassium in NO decomposition as a function of reaction temperature. Co-Mg-Mn-Al without alkali metal dopant shows no activity. As was expected, the NO decomposition activity was launched by potassium doping, which is in agreement with literature data [1]. Potassium is the most studied and effective promoter among other alkali metals. It is known that potassium has low ionization potential and thus easy transfers charge to the catalyst and by formation of the surface dipoles modifies the catalyst work function [47]. Since NO decomposition is oxidation–reduction reaction, the changes of work function should reflect in catalyst activities. Haneda et al. [1, 7, 20] examined direct NO decomposition on alkaline earth metal oxides supported on Co3O4 and proposed that the basicity of the catalyst is an important factor to enhance the activity. The key role of specific kind of medium basic sites on the catalyst surface, which are formed via presence of alkali metals, was also confirmed by other authors [48, 49] including our group [35, 50]. Our previous results show that potassium in Co–Mn–Al mixed oxide influenced not only the basic properties influencing NO adsorption and NOx storage ability, but also the redox properties, which are necessary for the activation of NO molecule and oxygen desorption [35]. The diversity of active surface sites enabling both processes to occur is thus essential for active catalyst performance. 3.3 Effect of different atmosphere during catalyst activation It was already reported that potassium doped Co mixed oxide catalysts need several hours to stabilize the performance after experimental launching, i.e. to reach the steady state [35]. It was supposed previously [34] that long stabilization time is connected with alkali metal vaporization and redistribution, which surely takes place within the reaction course. However, based on our recent laboratory experience we suppose that besides alkali vaporization, there could be also another reason. Therefore, the catalytic tests were conducted after activation in different atmospheres in order to see what happens during stabilization period of the catalytic test (time on stream). The activation was performed in inert gas (He or N2), or in oxidizing atmosphere consisting of 20 mol.% O2 in N2. Evolution of reaction products (N2 and O2) together with unreacted NO were monitored and compared to stoichiometry. NO conversions over K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al after activation in different atmospheres are presented in Fig. 3 . Results showed that the effect of activation in inert gasses (He and N2) is the same while a completely different course of NO conversion during stabilization period was observed after catalyst activation in an oxidizing atmosphere. Important finding is that the activation atmosphere did not affect NO conversion achieved at steady state. Measured composition of reaction mixture at the reactor outlet after activation in inert He and oxidizing atmosphere is shown in Fig. 4 and 5 , respectively. Activation in N2 was not included here since in this case, it was not possible to analyze small N2 concentration changes. The significant differences in concentrations of O2, N2 and NO were observed. The reason is that the catalyst treatment in inert gas at higher temperatures led to the oxygen desorption from catalyst since system try to reach equilibrium between oxygen concentration in gas and solid. As the result, oxygen vacancies were created [29, 51, 52] as was confirmed from XPS (Table 3) and TPR H2 (Fig. 1). Slow increase in NO concentration (up to 20 h) and delayed desorption of N2 (up to 8 h) and O2 (up to 20 h) after activation in inert conditions (Fig. 4) in comparison to theoretical concentration of N2 and O2 (calculated from NO conversion values) indicates slow NO adsorption and formation of NOx adspecies on the catalyst surface in agreement with our previous work [19]. Lower concentration of evolved O2 than N2 at the beginning of the reaction point out filling of lattice surface and subsurface oxygen vacancies, subsequent oxidation of adsorbed NO adducts and slower desorption of oxygen then nitrogen from catalyst after surface reaction. Results indicated that oxygen desorption is the slowest step of reaction. Relatively long time to reach steady state suggests that not only surface but also lattice oxygen in subsurface region is involved in the reaction. When catalyst was activated in oxidizing conditions (Fig. 5), the time to observe a constant NO concentration was much shorter, up to 5 h; the same time was necessary for achieving of theoretical concentration of released N2 and O2. Moreover, NO concentration at the outlet had very flat profile and was increasing in time a little bit in comparison with the activation in inert atmosphere where steep NO conversion decrease was observed. From the results of catalytic experiments and XPS, it is clear that activation atmosphere, inert or oxidizing, influences catalyst state and thus also catalyst performance at the beginning of the reaction. In case of oxidizing atmosphere, the surface and subsurface region is already filled with oxygen species after activation period. Slow growth of the NO conversion after activation in oxidizing atmosphere indicates regeneration of small part of active sites, which were deactivated during activation step by oxidation of the surface. From the comparison of both results it seems that oxidized surface, at least to some extent, is prerequisite for NO decomposition reaction which is in agreement with literature results [14]. Since N2 did not reach theoretical level at the beginning of the reaction in both cases, it can be deduced, that adsorption of NO is unavoidable step of reaction and that some nitrogen stays on the surface while forming NOx adspecies. Formation of NOx surface intermediates, already confirmed during NO decomposition on cobalt spinels surface by in-situ DRIFT [1, 19], represents important step for NO decomposition and only after that nitrogen can be evolved stoichiometrically. This step was in the literature directly related to the presence of alkali metals [8], which is in accordance with our results since cobalt mixed oxide without alkali metals shows no activity (see Fig. 2). 3.4 Effect of different concentration of NO and O2 in inlet reaction mixture NO direct decomposition at different NO inlet concentrations (400–8000 ppm NO in N2) is shown in Fig. 6 . In our case, negative or positive effect on reaction rate was not detected, constant NO conversion was achieved varying only within experimental error (± 5%). O2 desorbed during reaction as a reaction product (up to 3000 ppm) does not affect reaction rate within the range of tested inlet NO concentrations of 400–8000 ppm. Contradictory to previous finding, the presence of O2 in inlet gas mixture (even in concentrations below 2500 ppm) has significantly inhibiting effect (Fig. 7 ). The catalytic activity decreases with increasing concentration of O2, reaching very low constant value at 3 mol.% of oxygen. It was confirmed by independent experiment (Fig. 8 ) that the inhibiting effect is completely reversible. During catalytic tests in the presence of oxygen in reaction gas, it is possible that oxygen added to the inlet mixture can oxidize NO into NO2 before reaching the reactor in cold gas lines. For this reason, the influence of NO2 on the NO conversion was also tested. Effect of different contact times of O2 and NO in cold lines before the reactor and also separate test with NO2 directly added to the reaction mixture were performed at 700 °C. In this case, conversion of NOx instead of NO was evaluated. Results of these experiments (not shown) showed that different contact times of O2 and NO before the reactor as well as direct presence of NO2 (100 ppm) in inlet gas mixture had no effect on total NOx conversion. Negative effect of added oxygen was reported in many works [8, 10, 48, 53]. Mostly it is supposed that oxygen inhibition proceeds by occupying active sites by oxygen thus preventing NO adsorption and this retarding effect of oxygen become more significant at lower temperatures. Tofan [14, 33] specified the process in that way that oxygen acts as an inhibitor by blocking the renewal of appropriate active sites by oxidizing a specific NO species to nitrite or nitrate which are then desorbed as NO or NO2. Similar explanation was published by Haneda [8], who ascribed negative oxygen effect to NO3 − formation. In order to understand the oxygen effect more deeply, experimental data obtained over active K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst were used for kinetic study shown in the next paragraph. 3.5 Kinetic study Initial reaction rate method and kinetic Eq. (1) valid for initial reaction conditions were used for evaluation of reaction orders regarding to NO and O2 over active K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst. Initial reaction rate was determined from material balance of NO for isothermal ideal plug flow reactor according to Eq. (2): (1) r o = k ( p N O o ) n ( p O 2 o ) m (2) r o = [ d x N O d ( w n ˙ ) ] lim t → 0 where r o is initial reaction rate, k kinetic constant, p N O o initial partial pressure of NO, p O 2 o initial partial pressure of O2, n, m reaction orders regarding to NO and O2, respectively, x NO molar ratio of NO at the reactor outlet, w catalyst weight, n ˙ total molar flow, t = w n ˙ space time. Reaction orders n and m were calculated gradually from linearized form of Eq. (1) using NO conversion in oxygen-free inlet mixture (data on Fig. 6) and oxygen containing inlet mixture (data on Fig. 7, NO conversion < 30%), respectively. The reaction order with respect to NO for NO decomposition in inert gas was n = 1 (Fig. 9 (a)) which agrees well with published results over cobalt mixed oxides promoted by potassium [8, 25]. Contrary to our results, Iwakuni at al. [10] reported that NO conversion and N2 formation rate over perovskite catalyst increases with increasing NO partial pressure (from 0.1 to 1% NO) and the rate-determining step might be adsorption or activation of NO. The similar results was also achieved by Goto [53]. The reaction order with respect to O2 for NO decomposition in reaction mixture containing 1000 ppm NO and 0–10 mol.% O2 was m = −0.5 and is in accordance with published reaction orders varying between −1 and −0.5 [13, 54] over different type of catalysts. Negative reaction order is interpreted as oxygen inhibition due to competitive adsorption between NO and O2 on active sites [8, 25]. From number of published mechanisms and kinetic studies of NO decomposition, four kinetic models, proposed different active sites and surface intermediates, were used for data evaluation in this study. Model I has been proposed by Teraoka et al. over perovskite-type oxides [25]. In this model (Eq R1, R2, R3 and R4), two NO molecules are adsorbed onto a pair of adjacent oxide ion vacancies serving as the active site, (R2) is the rate-determining step, followed by desorption of N2 and O2: (R1) (R2) (R3) (R4) Here, [] represents an oxide ion vacancy. The corresponding kinetic equation is given by Eq. (3). (3) r = N k 2 K N O p N O 2 1 + K N O p N O + K O 2 p O 2 where N represents the total number of surface active sites, k 2 is the rate constant for the attack of the second NO molecule at the pair site (R2), and K NO and K O 2 , represents the adsorption equilibrium constants for NO and O2, respectively. Model II from Vannice et al. [55] described NO decomposition over alkaline earth and rare earth oxides. It proposed a Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism Eq R5, R6, R7 and R8 in which two adsorbed NO molecules leading to the formation of N2O intermediate is the rate-determining step Eq R6: (R5) 2 [NO (g) + * ↔ NO*] (R6) (R7) N2O* → N2 (g) + O* (R8) 2O* ↔ O2 (g) + 2* Here, * represents an empty active site. If the surface coverage of N2O is assumed to be small, due to its high reactivity, the following rate equation can be derived, (4) r = N k 6 K N O 2 p N O 2 ( 1 + K N O p N O + K O 2 1 / 2 p O 2 1 / 2 ) 2 where k 6 is the rate constant for the reaction of the adsorbed NO to N2O (R6). Model III published by Lunsford [13] over Ba/MgO proposed Eley–Rideal (E–R) mechanism (Eq R9, R10, R11 and R12), in which the reaction between the gas-phase NO and ionic NOx species, such as NO2 −, is assumed to be the rate-determining step. The rate equation derived from this mechanism is given by Eq. (5). (R9) NO (g) +O−* →NO2 −* (R10) (R11) N2O* → N2 (g) + O* (R12) 2O* ↔ O2 (g) + 2* (5) r = N k 10 K N O 2 p N O 2 1 + K N O p N O + K O 2 1 / 2 p O 2 1 / 2 where k 10 is the rate constant for the reaction between the gas-phase NO and a surface reactive species (Eq R10). The formally same kinetic equation can be derived for Model IV mechanism proposed by Haneda over K-doped Co3O4 [8] with NO2 −, N2O and N2O2 intermediates consisting from following steps Eq R13, R14, R15, R16 and R17. (R13) NO (g) + * ↔ NO* (R14) NO* + O2 − → NO2 −* + []− (R15) (R16) N2Ox* + (x-1)* → N2 (g) + xO* (x < 3) (R17) 2O* ↔ O2 (g) + 2* To elucidate what model can describe experimental data of NO decomposition over K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst, plots 1/r o – p o(O2), (1/r o)0.5 – p o(O2)0.5 and 1/r o – p o(O2)0.5 [8] were made from Eqs. (3), (4) and (5), respectively (Fig. 10 ). As can be seen in Fig. 10(a), no linear dependence of the inverse rate on O2 partial pressure can be observed, suggesting that the kinetic equation Eq. (4) and Model I are not applicable in our case. It means that NO decomposition does not proceed through the rate-determining step where two NO molecules are adsorbed onto a pair of adjacent oxide ion vacancies serving as the active sites. On the other hand, the other two kinetic equations ( Eq 4 and Eq 5) agree with the experimental data reasonably well (Fig. 9 (b) and (c)). Both kinetic equations suggest the reaction order regarding to NO to be between 1 and 2 and that regarding to O2 to be between 0 and −0.5, which is consistent with experimental observation. From the kinetic study we can conclude that NO decomposition over K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide can proceed through adsorbed nitrogen oxospecies (N2O, NO2 −, N2O2) as reaction intermediates. However, based only on kinetic data, we can´t distinguish between them and we also can´t distinguish between plausible mechanisms described by Models II, III and IV and confirm them. Moreover, other possible models of reaction mechanisms can also be described by the same kinetic equation as Eq. (5). Formation of NO2 − was confirmed by in situ DRIFT over K/Co3O4 [8] and K/Co4MnAlOx mixed oxide [19], where also presence of NO3 − was not excluded. Identification of surface species formed during NO decomposition over K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al is described below. 3.6 Temperature programmed desorption of NO Temperature programmed desorption of NO was performed to characterize various catalyst surface species present during catalytic reaction in the presence of oxygen as well as in oxygen absence. In order to differentiate as much species as possible, different types of procedures were applied (see 2.3 Temperature programmed desorption and transient state experiments). At first, signal profiles of NO (Fig. 11 ) and O2 (Fig. 12 ) were compared, when the sample was heated in He and when the sample was exposed to nitric oxide at temperature range from 650 to 50 °C after sample activation in different atmospheres – inert, oxidative or reductive. During all measurements (temperature desorption step), N2 was monitored but no N2 was generated. Therefore, nitrogen signal is not shown in figures for better clarity. No N2O and NO2 evolution was observed during all TPD NO tests, with one exception for N2O during saturation step during TPD explicitly mentioned in the text. TPD NO results show presence of several NOx and oxygen species on the surface after catalyst treatment in NO/He flow under cooling down from 650 to 50 °C. No evolving gasses (NO, N2, O2) were detected in experiment without previous NO adsorption step (sample heating) on potassium promoted sample, thus confirming that desorbed gasses observable in Fig 11 and 12 are produced due to NO adsorption and are not products of catalyst decomposition. Broad NO desorption profile with three main maxima around 150, 250 and 550 °C and with possible less significant maximum between 350 and 450 °C is observable in Fig. 11 over potassium modified sample indicating presence of NOx adspecies with different thermal stabilities. On the sample without potassium, NO desorption was observed only below 450 °C (Fig. 11) and with significantly lower intensities. However, three maxima are also clearly observable. Besides NO evolution, the oxygen was formed at the same time with desorption of NO at highest desorption temperature (550 °C) for K promoted Co-Mg-Mn-Al catalyst (Fig. 12); very flat peak was also observed around 250 °C. What is interesting is that effect of different pretreatment even by oxidation or reduction of the sample did not affect the shape of the TPD signals. The explanation can be deduced from the step increase of NO from 0 to 9 980 ppm at 650 °C (Fig. 13 -15), which was applied before temperature desorption ramp. After treatment in inert gas (Fig. 13), when NO (with Ar tracer) was dosed at 650 °C on the catalyst (NO saturation step), fast and steep increase of Ar and N2 is observed, followed by NO and slightly delayed O2. This behavior is similar to that observed previously on K/Co-Mn-Al [19], with the only exception, very small amount of N2O was observed together with N2 evolution (Fig. 13) on K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al sample. N2O formation stopped very quickly and was not observable again in any other experiments discussed in this article. This agrees with Haneda [8, 17] who proposed that over alkali metal doped Co3O4 catalysts, NO2 − species probably react with another NOx adspecies resulting in the formation of another intermediates N2Ox, which decompose very fast into gaseous N2 and adsorbed oxygen species. However, fast formation of N2O after applying NO at 650 °C on sample activated in inert atmosphere was previously observed in our laboratory also for other similar kind of samples, which means that it was not chance event. However, it should be mentioned that m/z = 44 signal attributed to N2O can be also attributed to CO2 signal. In our case this fact can´t be confirmed or excluded by monitoring any other N2O and CO2 fragments due to their very low signal intensity. In case when the sample was pre-oxidized (Fig. 14 ), the course of the Ar, N2 and NO signals is similar. The only difference is that oxygen signal is decreasing to a constant value, since the rest of the oxygen used for sample oxidation during previous step is flushing from the system together with the oxygen surplus from the surface. Since NO was also adsorbed on the sample in this case, it is obvious, that NO can be adsorbed on oxidized surface. The signals profiles greatly differ when the sample was pre-reduced before NO dosage (Fig. 15 ). In this case, fast evolution of nitrogen together with argon was observed, while oxygen and nitric oxide signals were extremely delayed. The N2 signal went through significant maximum before falling down to steady state value. This means that after contact of reduced catalyst with NO, all NO was consumed for catalyst reoxidation, while emerging N2 is directly evolved in the gas phase. With onward catalyst oxidation, less NO is consumed, amount of emerging N2 is decreasing and catalyst becomes working in steady state. The results show that NO is able to react with oxidized as well as reduced surface and after reaching steady state coverage of catalyst surface, the same active adspecies are formed, and these are consequently evolved during TPD ramp. Complex TPD NO profiles over metal oxide catalysts were also observed in the literature by other authors [21, 22, 24, 56] and our team [19]. Similar TPD NO profile was observed by Ishihara [24] for La(Ba)Mn(In)O3 perovskite catalysts. Ishihara [24] assigned (based on results of DRIFTS and TPD O2 isotopic profiles) the species to the molecularly adsorbed NO (weakly and strongly adsorbed NO−) and to NO3 − species formed by disproportionation adsorption of NO (3 NO + e − = N2 + NO3 −) or adsorption of NO on the strongly adsorbed surface oxygen NO + 2 O2 − = NO3 − + 3 e −). Pinho et al. [21] assigned (on the basis of DFT calculations for (100) surface of cobalt spinel nanocubes) low temperature peak (up to 100 °C) to the loosely bound mononitrosyl species associated to Co in octahedral positions (-ONCoO), medium band (100–300 °C) to NO released upon thermal decomposition of dinitrosyl –(ON)2CoT adducts (CoT means cobalt in tetrahedral position) and high temperature peak (300–500 °C) to decay of mononitrosyl –ONCoT adspecies. However, in [21] authors considered only NO adsorption at ambient temperature and did not consider NO decomposition and subsequent oxygen desorption, which was observable in our case. On K/Co-Mn-Al we have previously ascribed [19] the low temperature peak (~ 130 °C) to physically adsorbed NO molecule, the second peak (~ 290 °C) to nitrosyl anion NO− and the high temperature peak to NO from decomposition of nitrate and nitrite species. It is worth to be noted that in [19], the high temperature peak was probably composed from two peaks, which were not strictly differentiated. Desorbed N2 was not detected during TPD NO test. This can mean that N2 desorption during reaction is fast and no N2 stayed accumulated on the catalyst surface during reaction at 650 °C and even during cooling down in NO/He flow, in accordance with [19, 27]. Evolution of oxygen together with desorption of NO at the highest desorption temperature (550 °C) suggests the formation of NOx surface intermediates after NO adsorption and these decompose at high temperature range in accordance with [19, 24, 49]. However, oxygen signal decrease is much slower than decrease of NO signal at isothermal part of the measurement suggesting that the net oxygen peak consists from two different peaks and the high temperature one is responsible for desorption of oxygen from the surface by recombination of oxygen atoms. In order to evaluate O2/NO molar ratio from peak areas, TPD NO (after treatment in inert) was performed once more together with calibration procedure (Fig. 16 ) and the signals were deconvoluted into individual peaks (Fig. 17 and 18 ). Peak maxima and peak areas are given in Table 5 . It is clear that oxygen, besides very small flat peak around 250 °C, accompanies the NO desorption at the temperature between 500 and 600 °C (temperature region IV), while at temperature region 300–500 °C (region III) only NO is evolved. Evaluation of O2/NO molar ratio in region IV gives value of 0.5, confirming that in this region, NO2 − species are decomposed. This is in good agreement with Haneda et al. [8], where the surface species formed during NO decomposition over alkali metal doped Co3O4 catalysts were studied by diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectroscopy and NO2 − anion species were detected at the 50 °C and 500 °C, while no NOx species on the surface were detected at the 500 °C for Co3O4 containing no potassium promoter. It seems that NO species desorbed at temperature region IV are important for the catalyst activity, since these were not present on inactive sample containing no potassium (Fig. 11). Since the temperature regions I-III suits well to those presented in [21] where authors described TPD NO profile on Co3O4 sample without potassium, it is tempting to ascribe NOx species desorbed in I, II and III region to the loosely bound mononitrosyl species associated to surface Co3+ in octahedral positions, dinitrosyl adducts on Co2+ in tetrahedral position and mononitrosyl adspecies on Co2+ tetrahedral sites, respectively. This is in accordance with [23], who claimed that on transitional metals, the nonreactive adsorption of NO does not take place. When comparing temperature of O2 desorption during TPD NO (Fig. 16) (> 500 °C) and the temperature dependence of catalytic activity (Fig. 2), it is obvious that oxygen desorption begins at the similar temperature where the conversion curve begins. This indicates that oxygen desorption via surface nitrites decomposition is rate limiting in agreement with results in 3.3. Effect of different atmosphere during catalyst activation section as well as [1, 8, 19]. At higher temperatures, also O2 desorption by oxygen atoms recombination (deducted from oxygen peak deconvolution and presence of peak for oxygen in region V) accompanies the nitrite decomposition and rate of NO decomposition is accelerated with temperature. 3.7 Temperature programmed desorption of NO + O2 Since our aim was to understand the effect of oxygen, also TPD NO+O2 was performed. In this case, the saturation of catalyst with mixture of NO and O2 at 650 °C and during cooling to 50 °C was done. The results are shown in -Fig. 19, 20 and 21 and Table 5. In comparison to results of TPD NO, huge differences are observable. NO signal still consists of four peaks; however their distribution is totally different. The peak in region I is almost missing, and the peak in region III, which was not fully apparent in TPD NO is now obvious and confirms that deconvolution of the TPD profile into four peaks was logical. It is interesting that NO peak area in region III is comparable with the area of peak 3 from of TPD NO (Fig. 17). The same can be observed for oxygen, moreover oxygen desorption in region III is now present in contrast to TPD NO, where no oxygen was evolved. TPD NO+O2 showed what type of adsorbed species can form, when in the reaction mixture is not only NO but also oxygen. However, desorption of the product during TPD NO as well as TPD NO+O2 was performed into inert (He) stream, which means into stream with no partial pressure of oxygen. In order to see if these species would be also evolved into oxygen containing streams, TPD NO+O2 was performed in modified form - the desorption was performed not into He but into 2 mol.% O2 in He. Although the detection of small changes in oxygen excess was not very accurate, it can be seen (Fig. 22 ) that signal profiles are very close to those from TPD NO+O2 desorbed into He, which means that oxygen presence in the stream do not hinder desorption of NO and O2 but only causes adsorption of oxygen on such sites that are not occupied by oxygen in the inert atmosphere, i.e. the sites occupied by adsorbed NO. 3.8 Temperature programmed desorption of O2 The temperature programmed desorption of oxygen (TPD O2) was performed with aim to differentiate oxygen species adsorbed on the catalyst and evaluate if the origin of oxygen atoms (from O2 adsorption or NO decomposition) plays any role. TPD O2 (Fig. 23 ) was performed by two procedures differing in temperature used for oxygen adsorption (650 or 50 °C). Oxygen signals from TPD NO and TPD NO+O2 are also shown for comparison. The deconvolution of oxygen signals is shown in Fig. 24 and 25 and details are given in Table 5. It can be observed that desorption profiles from TPD NO and TPD O2 differ, which means that oxygen entities adsorbed on the catalyst surface are different depending on the origin of oxygen. Oxygen desorption starts around 160 °C, when previously adsorbed in O2 form, and continuously increasing desorption signal is observable with increasing temperature. Since the measurement was terminated at 650 °C, due to protection of set-up from possible destruction by vaporization of alkali metals, the course of oxygen desorption at higher temperatures is only speculative: it can be seen from the observed trend that main desorption of oxygen will probably proceed only above 650 °C. This means that adsorbed oxygen on this catalyst is bound strongly on the surface. Similar oxygen species were formed after oxygen adsorption at 650 °C and 50 °C, only in region II, more distinct peak was evident for sample where oxygen was desorbed at 650 °C similarly to oxygen signal from TPD NO. Further trend with increasing temperature is similar for both cases. According to literature [10], the peak 2 and 3 at temperatures lower than 430 °C were ascribed to physically adsorbed oxygen molecules and surface active species (O2 −, O2 2−). The peak 4 between 500 and 600 °C was assigned to superoxide O − species. The oxygen desorbing at temperatures above 600 to 800 °C was classified as lattice oxygen in literature [10, 29, 57] and its temperature maxima is dependent on chemical composition of catalyst. Although during our sample heating, no oxygen was evolved in studied temperature range 50–650 °C (Fig. 12), we suggest that oxygen applied to catalyst either at 50 or 650 °C can oxidize the surface and fill lattice oxygen vacancies. From this reason, we expect also evolution of lattice like oxygen species during subsequent TPD run manifested itself as peak 5. It is undoubtedly that much more oxygen was evolved during TPD NO in region IV and V than during TPD O2 suggesting diversity of surface adsorption sites, different stability and mobility of surface oxygen species and that oxygen adsorption may proceed by an activated process. It is interesting that if only oxygen is applied on the catalyst, only very low amount of oxygen is desorbed during TPD, however if oxygen is applied together with NO, high amount of O2 is desorbed during TPD run. That means that in the presence of NO, NOx adspecies are formed on the catalyst surface and much more oxygen can be accumulated on the surface. When comparing O2/NO molar ratio, the value of 0.6 is obtained in region IV, which is close to 0.5 confirming presence of surface nitrites and confirming that oxygen in the feed did not influence formation and decomposition of nitrite species. In region III, the ratio is 3.1 which seems very surprising and means that besides possible NOx species also a lot of oxygen was adsorbed on the surface, when exposed to NO+O2. The excess of evolved oxygen do not allow direct confirmation if the NO eluted in region III was bound on the surface in the form of NO or as some NOx adspecies. However, since the NO peak area in TPD NO as well as in TPD NO+O2 are very close to each other (Table 5) and during TPD NO no oxygen was evolved in this region III, it can be supposed, that simple desorption of NO and oxygen instead of decomposition of oxygenated entities took place. On the other hand, such huge amount of desorbing oxygen must be explained somehow; especially if we know that simple addition of oxygen (without NO presence) did not cause adsorption and subsequent desorption of such amount of oxygen (compare areas of oxygen desorption for TPD O2 and TPD NO+O2, Table 5). Since in the literature it is often presented that NO3 − is formed in the presence of O2 in reaction mixture [8, 13, 23], it would be logical if the desorbed oxygen came from decomposition of nitrates. This assumption is supported by stoichiometry calculated from Table 5. Area of oxygen desorbed in region III is comparable with the amount of NO desorbed in areas I-III plus oxygen desorbed from TPD O2 (650 °C) in region III. Therefore, we can assume that all three kinds of NO adspecies (region I-III) are oxidized to nitrates after contact with oxygen, while nitrite species (region IV) remained untached. Since NO peak in region I was negligible in TPD NO+O2, it can mean that this type of nitrate species are the most stable and did not decompose below 650 °C in contrast to nitrate types formed from NO adsorbed in region II and III. 4 Discussion No effect of oxygen formed from NO decomposition and severe inhibition by oxygen when present in the inlet mixture seems rather peculiar. Possible observations could be explained by NO2 recirculatory mechanism [27], where no oxygen originating from NO decomposition is in the gas phase near the catalyst surface, because it is supposed that only NO2 and N2 are desorbed from the catalyst after NO decomposition. Author claims that the O2 formation proceeds homogeneously in the hot part of the reactor downstream the catalyst bed from the desorbed NO2 (2NO2 (g) ↔ 2NO (g) + O2 (g)). However, our results do not support this explanation, because after NO switch off [19] there is no delay in NO evolution in comparison to O2 and no NO2 was observed during TPD NO experiments. We suppose that the reason is that during NO decomposition, high oxygen concentration is present only at the end of catalyst bed due to concentration profiles of reactants and products in axial direction of the catalytic bed. For that reason, resulting contact time is not sufficient for oxygen adsorption. This is in agreement with [14], who reported strong sensitivity of oxygen effect on the contact time and overall complicity of oxygen influence. The above experimental observations support our previous results published in [19], only the evidence for NO3 − formation was not observed in current work in case when there is no oxygen in the feed. At the beginning of NO catalytic decomposition, the NO adsorption appears and NO* is formed (Eq R18). Since the catalyst surface is heterogeneous from the point of view of cobalt and manganese cation coordination, three different kind of adsorbed NO species with different thermal stabilities are formed: the loosely bound mononitrosyl species associated to surface Co3+ and possibly also Mn3+ in octahedral positions (100–200 °C, region I in TPD NO), dinitrosyl adducts on Co2+ in tetrahedral position (200–300 °C, region II in TPD NO) and mononitrosyl adspecies on Co2+ tetrahedral sites (300–400 °C, region III in TPD NO). Moreover, nitrite species stable up to 600 °C (region IV in TPD NO) can be formed only on K containing catalyst when adsorbed NO reacts with oxygen atom (lattice or surface) (Eq R19). Nitrogen formation was observed directly after contact of NO with the surface (Eq R20) while the surface is partly reoxidized and nitrogen formation continues also by (Eq R21). Slightly delayed evolution of NO during NO switch on indicates NO adsorption on the catalyst surface, while delayed evolution of oxygen indicates that the formation of O2 do not directly proceeds from the collision of activated nitrogen oxides molecules but must proceed via some step, where oxygen is at first accumulated on the surface - dioxygen can form from recombination of the two oxygen atoms left on the surface (Eq R22) or from surface intermediates decomposition (Eq R23). At temperatures about 600 °C, reaction Eq R22 prevails and the complete catalytic cycle can run via reactions Eq R18, R19, R20 and R23. Eq R23 is not combination of Eq R22 and Eq R24, which means that surface nitrites directly decomposes into NO and oxygen as was confirmed by TPD NO measurement. At higher temperatures, lattice oxygen vacancies as well as lattice oxygen species (Eq R19, R21 and R25) can also participate in NO decomposition. (R18) NO chemisorption NO (g) + * ↔ NO* (R19) Surface nitrite formation NO* + O# or O* → NO2*+ # or * (R20) N2 desorption 2NO* → N2 + 2 O* (R21) NO2* + NO* + # → N2 + O# + 2 O* (R22) O2 desorption 2 O* ↔ O2 (g) (R23) 2NO2* → 2NO+ O2 (R24) NO2* → NO + O* (R25) O2 migration O* + # ↔ O# + * (R26) Surface nitrate formation NO* + O2 → NO3* where * is surface active site and # is lattice oxygen vacancy. In the presence of oxygen added to the feed gas, adsorbed NO is oxidized to NO3* (Eq R26) which does not decompose at applied reaction temperatures and does not act as active intermediate in the reaction and stops the NO decomposition reaction cycle. Based on TPD NO and TPD NO+O2 results, NO* reacting in Eq R20 and Eq R21 must be the loosely bounded NO (region I), since only such species are missing on the catalyst surface when oxygen was applied together with NO. Also oxygen vacancies can be lacking in order to run Eq R21, since some oxygen can oxidize the surface (Eq R22) as well as form lattice species (Eq R25) as was observed by TPD O2. The oxygen accelerates catalyst oxidation, if the surface is in reduced (partly reduced) form; however it is not essential reactant, since the reduced surface can be also oxidized by adsorbed NO (Eq R20, R21 and R24). We think that the oxidized surface is prerequisite for NO decomposition, but it is not necessary to use oxygen for that as was supposed by Tofan [14]. Our results support explanation that negative effect of oxygen added to the feed is due to oxidation of NO surface intermediates to more stable surface nitrate species [8, 14] and thus limiting the amount of loosely bound NO* species on the surface octahedral Co3+ and Mn3+ sites as well as due to the filling of oxygen vacancies. 5 Conclusions Investigation of oxygen effect on NO direct decomposition over K-promoted Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide brought following results. The catalytic activity decreased with increasing concentration of O2. Presence of O2 in gas mixture in concentrations higher than 0.5 mol.% had significantly inhibiting effect; however, the inhibiting effect was completely reversible. Contradictory to that, O2 desorbed during catalytic reaction as a reaction product did not affect reaction rate within the inlet NO concentration of 1000 - 8000 ppm. The presence of oxygen during activation led to a faster reaching of a steady state compared to activation in the inert. The reason is the formation of lattice oxygen vacancies; their filling with oxygen from the decomposition of NO causes a longer stabilization at the beginning of the reaction. Regardless of whether the activation took place in an oxidizing atmosphere or in an inert, the NO conversion achieved at steady state is the same. Observed severe oxygen inhibition was ascribed to oxidation of loosely bound NO* species on the surface octahedral Co3+ and Mn3+ sites to more stable surface nitrate species sites making NO* species limiting reactant. While oxygen desorption is the slowest reaction step, N2 desorption was observed to be very fast. Nitrite surface intermediates are indispensable reactive species and are formed only on potassium containing sample. All observed features pointed out to the fact that there is not just one active site on the catalyst surface but that active catalyst must possess diversity of active sites, which can cooperate with each other in order to run catalytic cycle of NO decomposition: transition metals represents sites necessary for NO chemisorption, while potassium ensures NO to nitrites oxidation which is in accordance to findings that optimal oxidation–reduction and acido-basic properties governs catalyst activity for NO decomposition. coredata.dc:description: Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide with or without K was prepared and characterized by XPS, TPR H2, TPD NO, TPD O2 and TPD NO+O2. NO decomposition was performed over catalyst activated in different atmosphere (N2, He, O2). Presence of oxygen during activation changed the course of surface stabilization but did not affect NO conversion achieved at steady state. O2 desorbed as a reaction product does not affect the reaction rate for NO inlet concentration of 400 - 8000 ppm, but presence of O2 in inlet gas mixture (0.05 - 3 mol.%) has significant inhibiting effect. Transition metals in octahedral coordination represent sites for NO chemisorption, while potassium ensures NO oxidation to surface nitrites, which are indispensable reactive species. Oxygen desorption was the slowest reaction step, while N2 desorption was fast. Oxygen inhibition was ascribed to oxidation of NO* species on the octahedral Co3+ and Mn3+ to more stable surface nitrates making NO* species as limiting reactant.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen effect in NO direct decomposition over K/Co-Mg-Mn-Al mixed oxide catalyst–Temperature programmed desorption study
